properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain will end by this afternoon. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. An area of freezing rain will move slowly eastward across region today. The freezing rain is expected to exit Lynn Lake and Pukatawagan areas this afternoon and the Thompson area this evening. ### Utility outages may occur. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.

properties.Summary:

Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions are likely Thursday night and Friday morning. A disturbance tracking from west central Kivalliq towards Foxe Basin is expected to bring blizzard conditions to Coral Harbour. As the system approaches the blizzard will be preceded by snow and strong southerly winds later this afternoon into this evening. Snowfall accumulations of 5 to 15 cm are possible along with blowing snow. Conditions will improve overnight however strong winds are expected to redevelop on the back side of the system late Thursday afternoon resulting in blizzard conditions. Northwest winds gusting to 90 km/h will create extensive blowing snow with conditions gradually improving Friday morning as the disturbance moves into Quebec. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-05T07:15:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-04T15:16:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3040993380.2020
Area: Coral Harbour
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A frontal system will approach the Central Coast this morning then move across the region into the BC interior this afternoon. As the front approaches, southeast winds of 40 to 60 km/h will develop this morning except 80 km/h along exposed coastal areas near midday. After the passage of the front this afternoon, southwest winds will develop and eventually reach speeds of 80 to 100 km/h tonight. These winds will ease early Thursday morning. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-05T06:03:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-04T14:04:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1940126655.2020
Area: Central Coast - coastal sections
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Fog will dissipate early this afternoon. Black ice may develop on surfaces as temperatures remain just below the freezing mark in some areas. Take extra care when walking or driving in affected areas. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Light winds and a moist air mass are creating widespread fog across central portions of Manitoba. The fog is expected to gradually lift this morning. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 10 cm is expected. A storm system will approach northeastern BC later today. Heavy snow is expected to develop by early this evening over the northern BC Peace River region and spread across the Fort Nelson region later that evening. Across the BC Peace, Gusty winds will accompany the falling snow with some areas experiencing periods of blowing snow. The snow will taper off near midnight over the BC Peace and be followed by a risk of freezing drizzle through the overnight hours. For the Fort Nelson area, snow is likely to ease during the early morning hours on Thursday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-05T03:44:54-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-04T11:45:54-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2002151481.2020
Area: B.C. North Peace River, Fort Nelson
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Heavy snow and freezing rain are forecast to begin this evening and end by Thursday morning. Total snowfall accumulations of 10 to 15 cm are expected in some areas. The freezing rain is expected to affect areas south of a line from Peace River to Wabasca. ### Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Summary:

A blizzard warning is issued when winds are expected to produce blowing snow with widespread visibilities of 400 metres or less for at least 6 hours. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions forecast for tonight and Thursday with conditions gradually improving by Friday. A disturbance tracking from east central Kivalliq towards Foxe Basin is expected to intensify as it moves across the region. Snow and blowing snow will develop over the Naujaat region later this afternoon and by this evening blizzard conditions are expected. Strong northerly winds gusting to 90 km/h will create near zero visibilities in blowing snow persisting throughout Thursday. Winds will diminish somewhat Thursday night but blizzard conditions will likely persist into early Friday morning before improving. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-05T07:15:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-04T15:16:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1669051816.2020
Area: Naujaat
properties.Author: Environment Canada
